comments.commentBody: Why yesssssss! Allow guns in schools! Every teacher and student should be armed to the teeth and then let the fun begin. Florida and my state, Ohio, are so disfunctional already where firearms are concerned.

It looks as though the relevant committee of the Florida House of Representatives might respond to the Newtown massacre by considering legislation to allow guns in schools.  The committee chair is Rep. Dennis Baxley of Ocala.  I doubt that any such proposal will pass, but the Tampa Bay Times didn't seem to find any enthusiasm at the state level for gun control (local governments have to conform to state law).
Everything you recommend was/is in place in Newton, Ct.

Not an unreasonable point to start with, though I'm sure both sides would wrangle over the details. Unfortunately there would have to be acceptance of federal preemption in order to codify uniform regulation across state lines, bringing thorny 10th and 14th amendment issues before the voters and the courts. It potentially opens a Pandora's box by way of the rabid fringes on either side, and the minutia would be debated, filibustered, tacked on to irrelevant legislation, etc. ad nauseum. Democracy sure is messy, isn't it?

Seeingwithopeneyes, you are incorrect. Only some guns needs to be registered, there is permitting not licensing, there is no required insurance or training with the permits.

It's a canard to point to CT gun laws as "one of the most restrictive in the country" then go on to argue that nothing more can be done w.r.t. guns as a public safety matter.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gun_laws_in_Connecticut

Gun safety is the right approach. With rights, come responsibilities (an old fashioned conservative concept). We need to treat guns as they are, useful, but a public safety concern, very similar to cars. You and I are impacted by a neighbor's failure to store or use guns correctly, just as you and I are impacted by a neighbor's failure to maintain his brakes or his driving when his sight is failing.

So, register all guns. Attach heavy fines and possible incarceration to any firearm found not registered.

License all gun buyers and carriers. Only licensed people can purchase a gun, in any venue (takes away that oft-cited burden on merchants).

Require for that license, proof of training including gun storage and concerns of access with respect to family members, and proof of liability insurance.

Implement this through amnesties, and applying heavy fine to guns found unregistered. There needn't be sweeps.

People can hunt, people can collect, people can target shoot, people can keep firearms for protection. But they owe the public these things, because they are introducing guns into the environment and that creates a public safety concern.

I agree this columnist is being quite unfair to the President. I mean, this issue affects ALL of us, and until everyone does something to convince our officials that reelection hinges on their commitment to gun law sanity in this country, we can't just say to Mr. Obama; just do it!

Changing views, culture, and tolerance for the unacceptable demands hard action by the majority who can shout down the fear-mongering zealots and paranoid crazies that see everything in black and white.

One person alone can't change attitude. It starts, and ends with, changing views like we heard from Joe Scarborough yesterday, one person at a time.
I agree except that as I read the 2nd amendment, Americans have no gun rights except as part of a "well regulated militia."

Please, Roger, let's be fair to President Obama.

The gun lobby, namely the NRA, like Grover Norquist and the 1% lobby, has always been overly aggressive with anyone they deemed anti-gun. Senator Feinstein's landmark bill on banning assault weapons was watered down over time and finally allowed to expire. Some Americans have protected their guns gun rights by misinforming the public, changing the meaning of the law to suit their views - anything as long as any and all weapons can still be sold. Then, when our African-American president was elected, gun sales went through the roof. They went through the roof again when he was reelected. That, however, has absolutely nothing to do with what happened on Friday, except for the little we know of Adam Lanza's mother and her affinity for weapons.

When Gabby Giffords was shot and President Obama gave his speech, I am sure he was sincere. But where were Gabby's colleagues then? Where have they been since?

What we know, today, is that almost all of the candidates supported by the NRA this election lost their bid for office. That's good. What we also know is that, finally, some of the staunchest defenders of the gun lobby are coming forward, one by one, and repudiating the NRA. That's excellent.

I've been calling for President Obama, if need be, to tell Speaker Boehner he won't sign any Fiscal Cliff bill unless he's presented with a real gun control bill. It's time to lead. We have your back. Just do it, Mr. President!

How about some rules prohibiting cross ownership of media assets.

Instagram is using the TOS that FB had before there was a big revolt on Facebook and they took that sort of big grab out.

It's not using the more progressive TOS that Linden Lab, for example, designed for Second Life way back in 2003 -- that users owned their own IP, and while their photos or digital content might be used in the company's ads without compensation, they would also own their own rights to digital content that they could sell. And that's why it has thrived and made profits for the companies and users both.

Kevin Systrom has a historical opportunity to turn the corner on the technocommunism that has made up our web 2.0 so far -- users upload content for free in a big collective far, but it's one of those "we pretend to work and you pretend to pay us" situations. There isn't any option to get paid or pay others.

Creative Commons is also to blame for creating a culture adversarial to commerce and browbeating people into "sharing".

Systrom could put in a user interface and payments system that enabled people to get paid for their photos by other users or commercial entities. They could take the proceeds. This will make their service boom. They simply have to do this.

We have an interesting thing going on here in northeastern CT.  Walmart has been building not just regular stores, but superstores in a concentration that far exceeds what one would expect in a rural area.  Within a year or so, there will be four superstores within 25 mile radius.  A superstore has a full service grocery section and a 24-hour operation.  Two of the stores are fully operational now, one is under construction and one is being expanded.  When all four stores are fully operational, it is my bet that they will put all the existing grocery stores out of business.  This is the Walmart business model: they dominate, control and overwhelm.
It's a necessary part of operating in Mexico!

Wish I could believe it were possible to force a clean sweep and culture change at Walmart, but alas, I don't.  Playing dirty hardball has been their success model.  Capitalism at some of its ugliest.

Excellent piece of journalism.  As someone reasonably familiar with the decision makings of large corporations, its quite apparent based on this article that within Walmart's senior echelons they have promoted a goal to grow by any means possible, whether unethical or unlawful.  Mistakes and bad decisions are made all the time, often by the best intentioned organizations.  And I believe the public generally understands and forgives honest mistakes or momentary lapses in judgment.  However in this instance it surely feels that Walmart has perpetuated a flawed set of values and culture.  This is a major problem for the company and its executives.  A wholesale change is in order (of mgmt, the board, etc) and the company and its mgmt team will need to assume the consequences, legal, financial, reputational and otherwise.

Truth will out, but not consequences.

The management and owners from the WalMart heirs to stockholders, including every fund that hold this stock, are far too many and powerful to resist.
